Introductory
	Entitlement to receive money towards costs of childcare
		This Act contains provision for HMRC to make payments (“top-up payments”)to be used towards the costs of qualifying childcare.
			For the meaning of “qualifying childcare”, see section 2.
		A person is entitled to receive a top-up payment for an entitlement periodin respect of a child if—
			the person is an eligible person for the entitlement period (see section3),
			the person has made a valid declaration of eligibility for the entitlementperiod (see section 4),
			the child is a qualifying child (see section 14),
			the person holds a childcare account in respect of the child (see section15), and
			a qualifying payment is made into the childcare account during theentitlement period (see section 19).
		HMRC must pay the top-up payment into the childcare account.
		The amount of the top-up payment is 25% of the amount of the qualifyingpayment.
		(For provision limiting the amount of qualifying payments that may be madeinto a childcare account in an entitlement period, see section 19(4).)
		Regulations may amend subsection (4) so as to substitute a differentpercentage for the percentage for the time being specified there.
		Sections 17 to 25 contain provision about childcare accounts, includingrestrictions on the kinds of payments that may be made from childcareaccounts.
		Sections 26 to 29 contain provision about obtaining and sharinginformation.
		Sections 30 to 34 contain special rules about persons who are claiming taxcredits or universal credit.
		Sections 35 to 55 contain provision about penalties and other enforcementpowers, including powers to recover top-up payments in certain circumstances.
		Sections 56 to 61 contain provision about reviews and appeals.
		Section 62 contains provision enabling HMRC in certain circumstances tocompensate persons who have been deprived of the opportunity to receive top-uppayments.
		Sections 63 and 64 contain provision for the withdrawal of tax exemptionsin respect of certain kinds of employer-provided childcare schemes.
	Qualifying childcare
		In this Act “childcare” means any form of care or supervised activity for achild that is not provided in the course of the child’s compulsory education.
		Childcare that is provided for a person is “qualifying childcare” for thepurposes of this Act if—
			it is registered or approved childcare, and
			the main reason, or one of the main reasons, for incurring the costs of thechildcare is—
			to enable the person to work, or
			where the person has a partner, to enable both the person and the person’spartner to work.
		Regulations may—
			make provision about what is, or is not, to be regarded as registered orapproved childcare for the purposes of this section;
			define what is meant by “work” for the purposes of this section;
			specify cases where the condition in subsection (2)(b) is to be treated asmet;
			specify cases where that condition does not need to be met.
		Regulations made under subsection (3)(a) may, in particular, provide thatchildcare provided outside the United Kingdom is registered or approvedchildcare if it is provided by a person approved by an organisation that isaccredited by a person or body under an enactment.
		Subsection (2) is subject to any direction made under section 50 (whichenables HMRC in certain circumstances to direct that childcare provided by aperson is not qualifying childcare).

Eligibility
	Eligible persons
		A person is an eligible person for an entitlement period if—
			the person meets the conditions of eligibility in sections 6 to 13, and
			in a case where the person has a partner, the person’s partner meets theconditions of eligibility in sections 9 to 13.
		In sections 6 to 13 “the date of the declaration” means the day on whichthe person makes a declaration of eligibility for the entitlement period (seesection 4).
		Sections 6 to 13 need to be read with—
			regulations made under them, and
			regulations made under subsection (4).
		Regulations may provide for exceptions to the requirement for any of theconditions of eligibility in sections 6 to 13 to be met by a person.
		Regulations may make provision about when a person is, or is not, to beregarded as another person’s partner for the purposes of this Act.
	Declarations of eligibility
		For the purposes of this Act a “declaration of eligibility” is a statementmade by a person for an entitlement period which states that the person is aneligible person for the entitlement period.
		A declaration of eligibility made by a person for an entitlement period is“valid” for the purposes of this Act if—
			HMRC are satisfied that the person is an eligible person for theentitlement period,
			on the day on which the declaration is made, there is no other person who—
			holds an active childcare account in respect of the relevant child (seesubsection (4)), or
			is seeking to hold an active childcare account in respect of that child(see subsection (5)), and
			the declaration is made in accordance with regulations under this section.
		But subsection (2)(b) does not apply for the purpose of determining whethera declaration of eligibility made for the purposes of opening a childcareaccount is valid (see instead section 17(2)(c)).
		In subsection (2)(b) “the relevant child” means the child in respect ofwhom the person making the declaration holds a childcare account.
			For what is meant by an “active” childcare account, see section 17(3).
		For the purposes of this section a person is “seeking to hold an activechildcare account” if—
			the person has applied to open a childcare account and the application hasnot yet been determined,
			the person has made a valid declaration of eligibility for an entitlementperiod which has not yet begun, or
			the person has made a declaration of eligibility for an entitlement periodwhich, if valid, would result in the person holding an active childcareaccount for that period.
		Regulations may make further provision about declarations of eligibility,including, in particular—
			provision specifying, or enabling HMRC to specify, information which aperson making a declaration of eligibility is required to provide to HMRC;
			provision specifying, or enabling HMRC to specify, the form and manner inwhich declarations of eligibility may be made;
			provision specifying the times when declarations of eligibility may bemade;
			provision about the consequences of making a declaration of eligibility—
			after the beginning of the entitlement period for which it is made, or
			at such other time as may be specified;
			provision for any consequences specified by virtue of paragraph (d) not toapply in specified circumstances or if specified conditions are met;
			provision specifying circumstances in which a person, or a person of aspecified description, may make a declaration of eligibility on anotherperson’s behalf, including provision enabling HMRC to appoint a person forthat purpose;
			provision treating things done, or omitted to be done, by a person whomakes a declaration of eligibility on another person’s behalf as having beendone, or omitted, by that other person.
		In subsection (6) “specified” means specified in the regulations.
	Entitlement periods
		The length of an entitlement period is 3 months.
			This is subject to the following provision.
		Regulations may—
			amend subsection (1) so as to alter the length of an entitlement period,and
			in consequence of any provision made under paragraph (a), amend anyreference in this Act to a period which begins on the day on which adeclaration of eligibility is made and is the same length as an entitlementperiod.
		Regulations may make further provision about entitlement periods,including, in particular—
			provision for determining when entitlement periods are to begin or end, and
			provision enabling HMRC, in circumstances specified in the regulations, tovary the length of an entitlement period in particular cases.
		Provision made by virtue of subsection (3)(b) may not enable HMRC to varythe length of an entitlement period by more than a month.

Conditions of eligibility
	The person must be 16 or over
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if the person isat least 16 years old on the date of the declaration.
	The person must be responsible for the child
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if, at the dateof the declaration, the person is responsible for the relevant child.
		In subsection (1) “the relevant child” means the child in respect of whomthe person holds, or wishes to open, a childcare account.
		Regulations may make provision as to the circumstances in which a personis, or is not, to be regarded as responsible for a child for the purposes ofthis Act.
	The person must be in the UK
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if the personis in the United Kingdom on the date of the declaration.
		Regulations may—
			specify circumstances in which a person is to be treated as being, or notbeing, in the United Kingdom;
			specify circumstances in which temporary absence from the United Kingdom isdisregarded;
			modify the application of this Act in relation to persons of a specifieddescription who are treated as being in the United Kingdom for the purposes ofthis Act.
		In subsection (2) “specified” means specified in the regulations.
	The person and his or her partner must be in qualifying paid work
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if the personis in qualifying paid work on the date of the declaration.
		Regulations may—
			make provision as to what is, or is not, qualifying paid work, and
			specify circumstances in which a person is, or is not, to be regarded as insuch work.
		Regulations under subsection (2) may, in particular—
			make provision for calculating a person’s expected income from any work fora period specified in the regulations,
			provide that a person is in qualifying paid work only if the person’sexpected income from the work for the period, taken together with the person’sexpected income from any other work for the period, is greater than or equalto an amount specified in, or determined in accordance with, the regulations,and
			specify cases in which the condition mentioned in paragraph (b) does notneed to be met.
	The income of the person and his or her partner must not exceed limit
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if, at the dateof the declaration, the person’s expected income for the relevant tax year isnot greater than an amount specified in, or determined in accordance with,regulations for the purposes of this section.
		Regulations may make provision for calculating a person’s expected incomefor a tax year.
		Regulations may provide that a person is treated as meeting the conditionof eligibility in this section (whether or not any provision has been madeunder subsection (1)) if the person does not expect to pay income tax at theadditional rate or the dividend additional rate for the relevant tax year.
		Regulations may provide that a person is treated as not meeting thecondition of eligibility in this section in any of the following cases—
			if the person has made, or expects to make, a claim under section 809B ofthe Income Tax Act 2007 (claim for remittance basis to apply) for the relevanttax year;
			if the person expects section 809E of that Act (application of remittancebasis in certain cases without claim) to apply to the person for the relevanttax year;
			if the person meets any other conditions specified in the regulations.
		In this section “the relevant tax year”, in relation to a declaration ofeligibility, means the tax year in which the date of the declaration falls.
	Neither the person nor his or her partner may be claiming universalcredit
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if, at the dateof the declaration—
			universal credit is not payable to the person in respect of any relevantassessment period (see subsection (2)), and
			there is no subsisting claim that would result in universal credit becomingpayable to the person in respect of a relevant assessment period.
		In subsection (1) “relevant assessment period”, in relation to adeclaration of eligibility, means any assessment period (within the meaning ofthe relevant legislation) that includes—
			the date of the declaration, or
			the whole or any part of the entitlement period for which the declarationis made.
		For the purposes of subsection (1) universal credit is payable to a personin respect of a relevant assessment period if it would be so payable but forthe reduction of the award of universal credit to nil under the relevantlegislation.
		In the case of a declaration of eligibility made for the purposes ofopening a childcare account, the reference in subsection (2) to theentitlement period for which the declaration is made is to be read as areference to the period of 3 months beginning with the date of thedeclaration.
		Regulations may specify other circumstances in which a person is to betreated as meeting, or not meeting, the condition of eligibility in thissection.
		In this section “the relevant legislation” means—
			Part 1 of the Welfare Reform Act 2012, or
			any provision made for Northern Ireland which corresponds to that Part ofthat Act.
	The person and his or her partner must not be in a relevant childcarescheme
		A person (“P”) meets the condition of eligibility in this section if, atthe date of the declaration—
			P is not an eligible employee in relation to a relevant childcare scheme(see subsections (2) and (3)),
			in a case where the declaration is made for the purposes of opening achildcare account, P intends to give P’s employer a childcare account notice(see subsection (4)) before the end of the period of 3 months beginning withthe date of the declaration, or
			in a case where—
			the declaration is not made for the purposes of opening a childcareaccount, and
			P is a new partner of the person making the declaration (see subsection(5)),
				P intends to give P’s employer a childcare account notice before the end ofthe entitlement period for which the declaration is made.
		“Relevant childcare scheme” means—
			a scheme under which qualifying childcare vouchers (within the meaning ofsection 270A of ITEPA 2003) are provided for employees, or
			a scheme under which care for a child is provided for employees incircumstances in which conditions A to D in section 318A of ITEPA 2003 aremet.
		“Eligible employee”—
			in relation to a scheme within subsection (2)(a), has the meaning given bysection 270AA of ITEPA 2003, and
			in relation to a scheme within subsection (2)(b), has the meaning given bysection 318AZA of that Act.
		“Childcare account notice”, in relation to a person who is an eligibleemployee in relation to a relevant childcare scheme, means a written noticeinforming the employer that the employee wishes to leave the scheme in orderto be able to open a childcare account or enable the employee’s partner to doso.
		For the purposes of this section P is a person’s new partner at the date ofthe declaration made by the person if P has not been the person’s partner atany time when the person has previously made a valid declaration ofeligibility.
		For provision enabling HMRC to recover top-up payments where P fails togive P’s employer a childcare account notice as mentioned in subsection (1)(b)or (c), see section 39.
	Neither the person nor his or her partner may be receiving otherchildcare support
		A person meets the condition of eligibility in this section if, at the dateof the declaration—
			no other relevant childcare support is payable to the person in respect ofany relevant period, and
			the person has not made, and does not intend to make, a claim that wouldresult in any other relevant childcare support becoming payable to the personin respect of any relevant period.
		“Other relevant childcare support” means any payments towards the costs ofchildcare which are made out of funds provided by a national authority, otherthan—
			payments under this Act, or
			payments of a description specified in regulations.
		In subsection (2) “national authority” means any of the following—
			a Minister of the Crown (within the meaning of the Ministers of the CrownAct 1975);
			the Scottish Ministers;
			the Welsh Ministers;
			a Northern Ireland department.
		“Relevant period”, in relation to a declaration of eligibility, means aperiod which—
			includes the date of the declaration,
			includes the whole or any part of the entitlement period for which thedeclaration is made, or
			falls within that entitlement period.
		In the case of a declaration of eligibility made for the purposes ofopening a childcare account, any reference in subsection (4) to theentitlement period for which the declaration is made is to be read as areference to the period of 3 months beginning with the date of thedeclaration.

Childcare accounts
	In this Act “childcare account” means an account which—
		is held by a person for the purpose of receiving top-up payments in respectof a qualifying child,
		is provided by a person or body within section 16(1),
		satisfies the requirements imposed by or under this Act, and
		has been opened in accordance with this Act.
	Each childcare account must be held in respect of one child only.
	Regulations may—
		impose other requirements which must be satisfied in relation to childcareaccounts, and
		make provision about the way in which payments may be made into, or from,childcare accounts.
	Regulations may provide that a person of a specified description may, ormay in specified circumstances, manage a childcare account on behalf of theaccount-holder.
	The provision that may be made by regulations under subsection (4)includes—
		provision enabling HMRC to appoint a person for the purpose of managing achildcare account on the account-holder’s behalf, and
		provision specifying functions in relation to the management of a childcareaccount which persons, or persons of a specified description, may not performon an account-holder’s behalf.
	In subsections (4) and (5) “specified” means specified in the regulations.
	Where a contract is entered into by or on behalf of a person who is 16 or17 years old in connection with a childcare account held by the person, thecontract has effect as if the person had been 18 or over when it was enteredinto.
	If the Commissioners so consent, fees may be charged in connection with achildcare account by the account provider.
	But the account provider may not charge any fees merely for—
		providing a childcare account,
		enabling a qualifying payment to be made into a childcare account (seesection 19), or
		enabling a payment to be made from a childcare account in respect ofqualifying childcare for the child in respect of whom the account is held.
	In this Act—
		the “account-holder”, in relation to a childcare account, means the personwho holds the childcare account, and
		the “account provider”, in relation to a childcare account, means theperson or body who provides the childcare account.

Account providers
	Childcare accounts may be provided by any of the following—
		the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs,
		a person or body with whom the Commissioners have entered into arrangementsfor the provision of childcare accounts, and
		if the Treasury so determine, the Director of Savings (“the Director”).
	If the Director provides childcare accounts, the Director must in doing soact in accordance with any arrangements made between the Director and theCommissioners with respect to the provision of childcare accounts.
	Arrangements made between the Commissioners and a person or body withinparagraph (b) or (c) of subsection (1) may include provision for the making ofpayments by the Commissioners to the person or body in respect of theprovision of childcare accounts (and accordingly nothing in section 15(8) or(9) affects the inclusion of such provision in the arrangements).
	If the Commissioners provide childcare accounts—
		any reference to the account provider paying an amount to HMRC from achildcare account, or to HMRC directing the account provider to do so, is tobe read as a reference to HMRC deducting the amount from the account,
		any requirement for the account provider to notify HMRC of any matter, orfor HMRC to notify the account provider of any matter, is to be disregarded,and
		any requirement for the account provider to give anything to HMRC, or forHMRC to give anything to the account provider, is to be disregarded.

Opening a childcare account
	A person who wishes to receive top-up payments (the “applicant”) must makean application to HMRC to open a childcare account.
	HMRC may grant the application only if—
		the applicant has made a valid declaration of eligibility,
		the child in respect of whom the account is to be held (“the relevantchild”) is a qualifying child at the date of the application, and
		on the day on which the application is granted, there is no other personwho holds an active childcare account in respect of the relevant child (seesubsection (3)).
	For the purposes of this Act a childcare account is “active” at any timeif—
		qualifying payments may be made into the account at that time (see section19), or
		such payments could, in the absence of section 19(4) (limit on amount ofqualifying payments that may be made in entitlement period), be made into theaccount at that time.
	Regulations may make further provision about opening a childcare account,including, in particular—
		provision about the making of applications to open a childcare account,including provision enabling HMRC to specify the form and manner in which suchapplications may be made;
		provision specifying, or enabling HMRC to specify, information whichapplicants must provide to specified persons or to persons of a specifieddescription;
		provision specifying circumstances in which a person, or a person of aspecified description, may make an application to open a childcare account onbehalf of an applicant, including provision enabling HMRC to appoint a personfor that purpose;
		provision requiring HMRC to provide specified information to specifiedpersons or to persons of a specified description.
	In subsection (4) “specified” means specified in the regulations.

Cases where there is more than one eligible person
	If two or more persons have applied to open a childcare account in respectof the same child, HMRC may determine which of them (if any) may open achildcare account in respect of the child.
	If— 
		a person—
		has applied to open a childcare account in respect of a child, or
		wishes to make a declaration of eligibility in relation to a childcareaccount held in respect of a child, and
		another person holds a childcare account in respect of the child,
			HMRC may determine which of them (if any) may hold an active childcare accountin respect of the child (see section 17(3)).
	For provision enabling HMRC to make an account restriction order to giveeffect to a determination under subsection (2), see section 24.

Payments into childcare accounts
	In this Act “qualifying payment” means any payment made into a childcareaccount, other than—
		a top-up payment, or
		a repayment of the whole or part of any payment made from the childcareaccount.
			But for the purposes of paragraph (b) a withdrawal made by the account-holderis not to be regarded as a payment made from a childcare account.
	Any person (including the account-holder) may make a qualifying paymentinto a childcare account during an entitlement period, provided that—
		the account-holder has made a valid declaration of eligibility for theentitlement period, and
		the child in respect of whom the account is held is a qualifying child atthe time of the payment.
		This is subject to any provision made by or under this Act.
	More than one qualifying payment may be made into a childcare accountduring an entitlement period.
	But the sum of any qualifying payments made into a childcare account in anentitlement period must not exceed the relevant maximum for the entitlementperiod.
	The relevant maximum for an entitlement period is £2,000.
	This is subject to subsection (6).
	Regulations may provide, or enable HMRC to provide, that in circumstancesspecified in the regulations the relevant maximum for an entitlement period isan amount—
		specified in, or determined in accordance with, the regulations, or
		determined by HMRC in accordance with powers conferred by the regulations.
	Regulations may amend subsection (5) so as to substitute a different amountor amounts for any amount for the time being specified there.
	For the purposes of subsection (4), any amount paid into a childcareaccount at any time during an entitlement period is to be disregarded if at alater time during the entitlement period an equivalent amount is withdrawnfrom the account by the account-holder.
	The account provider must notify HMRC of any qualifying payments made intoa childcare account.

Payments that may be made from childcare accounts
	The only payments which the account-holder may authorise to be made from achildcare account are—
		payments in respect of qualifying childcare for the relevant child, and
		withdrawals made by the account-holder.
	In this section “the relevant child”, in relation to a childcare account,means the child in respect of whom the account is held.
	A payment within subsection (1) is referred to in this Act as a permittedpayment.
	A payment made from a childcare account which—
		is not a permitted payment, and
		is not made by the account provider to HMRC under this Act,
			is referred to in this Act as a prohibited payment.
	Permitted payments may be made from a childcare account in an entitlementperiod whether or not the account-holder has made a valid declaration ofeligibility for the entitlement period.
	Where— 
		a payment is made from a childcare account, and
		only part of the payment is in respect of qualifying childcare for therelevant child,
		so much of the payment as is properly attributable to the costs of qualifyingchildcare for the relevant child is to be treated as a permitted payment, andthe remainder is to be treated as a prohibited payment.
	Regulations may make provision for determining, for the purposes ofsubsection (6), how much of a payment is properly attributable to the costs ofqualifying childcare for the relevant child.
	For the meaning of “qualifying childcare”, see section 2.

Calculating the top-up element of payments etc
	For the purposes of this Act the “top-up element” of any amount is anamount equal to the relevant percentage of that amount.
	The “relevant percentage” is the percentage given by—
		[![](/ukpga/2014/28/images/ukpga_20140028_en_001)](/ukpga/2014/28/images/ukpga_20140028_en_001?view=plain)
	where R is the percentage for the time being specified in section 1(4).

Withdrawals 
	Where the account-holder makes a withdrawal from a childcare account, theaccount provider must pay the corresponding top-up amount to HMRC from thechildcare account.
	The “corresponding top-up amount”, in relation to a withdrawal, is R% ofthe amount of the withdrawal, where R is the percentage for the time beingspecified in section 1(4).
	Accordingly, the maximum amount that may be withdrawn from a childcareaccount at any time is the relevant percentage of the total amount of fundsheld in the account at that time.
	The “relevant percentage” is the percentage given by—
		[![](/ukpga/2014/28/images/ukpga_20140028_en_002)](/ukpga/2014/28/images/ukpga_20140028_en_002?view=plain)
	where R is the percentage for the time being specified in section 1(4).
	A withdrawal may not be made from a childcare account at any time when atop-up payment is payable into the account.

Refunds of payments made from childcare accounts
	Where— 
		a payment is made to a person from a childcare account, and
		the whole or part of the payment is repayable by that person to theaccount-holder,
			so much of the payment as is repayable must be repaid by that person into thechildcare account.
	Where— 
		a payment made to a person consists of an amount paid from a childcareaccount and an amount that is not paid from the childcare account, and
		the whole or part of the payment (“the repayable amount”) is repayable bythat person to the account-holder,
		so much of the repayable amount as exceeds the amount not paid from thechildcare account must be repaid by that person into the childcare account.
	In a case where—
		a person would (in the absence of this subsection) be required bysubsection (1) or (2) to repay an amount (“the repayable amount”) into achildcare account, but
		the childcare account has been closed,
		the person must pay the repayable amount to the person or body who was theaccount provider in relation to the account (“the relevant account provider”).
	The relevant account provider must—
		pay the top-up element of the repayable amount to HMRC, and
		pay the remainder of that amount to the person who held the childcareaccount.
		(For provision about calculating the top-up element of an amount, see section21.)

Closure of childcare accounts
	Regulations may make provision about closing childcare accounts.
	The provision that may be made by regulations under this section includes,in particular—
		provision requiring a childcare account to be closed in specifiedcircumstances or if specified conditions are met;
		provision about what is to happen to any funds held in a childcare accountwhen it is closed;
		provision for the repayment to HMRC of a proportion of any such funds,calculated in accordance with the regulations.
	In subsection (2) “specified” means specified in the regulations.

Information
	Power to obtain information or documents
		HMRC may by notice in writing require a person of a description specifiedin regulations to provide information or documents which HMRC require inconnection with their functions under this Act.
		HMRC may require a person to provide information or a document only if itis in the person’s possession or power.
		Regulations may make provision about notices under subsection (1),including, in particular—
			provision requiring a notice to contain information specified in theregulations;
			provision requiring, or enabling a notice to require, information ordocuments to be provided in a form or manner specified in the regulations orthe notice;
			provision requiring, or enabling a notice to require, information ordocuments to be provided at a time, or within a period, specified in theregulations or the notice;
			provision requiring, or enabling a notice to require, information ordocuments to be provided in respect of a period specified in the regulationsor the notice;
			provision specifying descriptions of information or document which a noticemay not require a person to provide;
			provision about determining in specified cases whether information ordocuments are of such a description, including provision for thatdetermination to be made by a person or body specified in the regulations.
	Information sharing between HMRC and others
		Subsection (2) applies to information which is held as mentioned in section18(1) of the Commissioners for Revenue and Customs Act 2005 (confidentiality).
		Information to which this subsection applies may be disclosed to any personfor use for the purpose of enabling or assisting the exercise of any of thefunctions of HMRC under this Act.
		Information disclosed in reliance on subsection (2) may not be furtherdisclosed to any other person without the authority of the Commissioners(which may be general or specific).
		A person who holds information may disclose that information to HMRC if thedisclosure is made for the purposes of the exercise by HMRC of their functionsunder this Act.
		This section does not limit the circumstances in which information may bedisclosed apart from this section.
		In section 127 of the Welfare Reform Act 2012 (information-sharing betweenSecretary of State and HMRC), in subsection (7), in the definition of “HMRCfunction”—
			at the end of paragraph (a), omit “or”, and
			at the end of paragraph (b) insert “, or
			which is conferred by or under the Childcare Payments Act 2014;”.
	Wrongful disclosure of information received by others from HMRC
		If revenue and customs information relating to a person is disclosed incontravention of section 27(3) and the identity of the person—
			is specified in the disclosure, or
			can be deduced from it,
				section 19 of the Commissioners for Revenue and Customs Act 2005 (wrongfuldisclosure) applies in relation to the disclosure as it applies in relation toa disclosure of such information in contravention of section 20(9) of thatAct.
		“Revenue and customs information relating to a person” has the meaninggiven by section 19(2) of the Commissioners for Revenue and Customs Act 2005.
	Supply of information to HMRC by childminder agencies
		In section 83A of the Childcare Act 2006 (supply of information to HMRC etc bychildminder agencies), in subsection (2), in paragraph (b), for the words from“for the purposes of” to the end of that paragraph substitute “for thepurposes of—
			their functions in relation to tax credits, or
			their functions under the Childcare Payments Act 2014;”.

Special rules affecting tax credit and universal credit claimants
	Termination of tax credit awards
		In this section “the relevant day”, in relation to a person who has made adeclaration of eligibility for an entitlement period, means—
			the first day of the entitlement period, or

	Recovery of top-up payments where tax credits award made on a review
		This section applies where—

		P is liable to pay HMRC an amount equal to the sum of—
			any top-up payments made to P for an entitlement period falling whollywithin the relevant period, and
			the relevant proportion of the sum of any top-up payments made to P for anentitlement period falling partly within the relevant period.
		The “relevant period” means the period in relation to which the followingconditions are met—
			it falls within the review period (see subsection (4)),
			it is a period for which an award of a tax credit is made, or continues, asa result of the variation or cancellation of the decision, and
			where the award has been made to P and P’s partner on a joint claim, theperson who was P’s partner at the time of the claim has been P’s partnerthroughout the period.
		The “review period” means the period which—
			begins with the day on which the decision was made, and
			ends with—
			the day on which the person who applied for the review is notified of itsconclusions, or

		In subsection (2)(b) the “relevant proportion”, in relation to top-uppayments made for an entitlement period, means a proportion equal to theproportion of the entitlement period which falls within the relevant period.

Penalties
	Penalties for inaccurate declarations of eligibility
		A person is liable to a penalty under this section if the person meetscondition A or B.
		Condition A is that—
			the person makes a declaration of eligibility that contains an inaccuracy,and
			the inaccuracy is careless or deliberate.
				An inaccuracy is careless if it is due to a failure by the person to takereasonable care.
		Condition B is that—
			a declaration of eligibility containing an inaccuracy is made by or onbehalf of a person,
			the person discovers the inaccuracy after the declaration of eligibilityhas been made, and
			the person fails to take reasonable steps to inform HMRC.
		In a case where the inaccuracy is deliberate, the amount of the penalty is50% of the maximum available top-up payment for the entitlement period forwhich the declaration of eligibility was made.
		In any other case, the amount of the penalty is 25% of the maximumavailable top-up payment for the entitlement period for which the declarationof eligibility was made.
		“The maximum available top-up payment” for an entitlement period is theamount that would be payable by HMRC if qualifying payments equal to therelevant maximum for the entitlement period were made into the childcareaccount in respect of which the declaration was made.
		(For the relevant maximum for an entitlement period, see section 19(5) and(6).)
		If— 
			in the absence of this subsection, the relevant maximum for the entitlementperiod for which the declaration of eligibility was made would be the amountspecified in section 19(5), but
			the person made representations to HMRC that the relevant maximum for theentitlement period should be a greater amount determined by or underregulations under section 19(6),
			then for the purposes of subsection (6) above the relevant maximum for theentitlement period is to be taken to be that greater amount.
	Penalties for failure to comply with information notice
		If— 
			a person fails to comply with a notice under section 26 (an “informationnotice”) before the end of the period within which the person was required tocomply with it, and
			the information notice has become final (see subsection (6)),
				HMRC may give the person a warning notice.
		A “warning notice” is a notice requiring the person to comply with theinformation notice before the end of the period of 30 days beginning with theday on which the warning notice is given.
		If a person fails to comply with a warning notice given under this section,the person is liable to a penalty under this section.
		The amount of the penalty may not exceed £300.
		Regulations may amend subsection (4) so as to substitute a different amountfor the amount for the time being specified there.
		An information notice becomes final—
			in a case where the person does not apply for a review of the decision togive the information notice within the period specified in section 57(2)(a),at the end of that period,
			in a case where—
			the person applies for a review of the decision but does not give notice ofan appeal against the decision, and
			the decision has not been cancelled,
			at the end of the period in which notice of an appeal against the decisioncould have been given, or
			in a case where—
			notice of such an appeal has been given, and
			the decision has not been quashed on appeal,
			on the day on which the appeal is determined or withdrawn.
		Accordingly— 
			if a person is granted an extension of the period for making an applicationfor a review of a decision to give an information notice, any warning noticegiven to the person in respect of the information notice before theapplication for the review is made is of no effect, and
			if a person is permitted to give notice of an appeal against an informationnotice after the end of the period mentioned in subsection (6)(b), any warningnotice given to the person in respect of the information notice before thenotice of appeal is given is of no effect.
	Penalties for providing inaccurate information or documents
		A person is liable to a penalty under this section if—
			in complying with a notice under section 26, the person provides inaccurateinformation or provides a document that contains an inaccuracy, and
			condition A, B or C is met.
		Condition A is that the inaccuracy is careless or deliberate.
			An inaccuracy is careless if it is due to a failure by the person to takereasonable care.
		Condition B is that the person knows of the inaccuracy at the time theinformation or document is provided but does not inform HMRC at that time.
		Condition C is that the person—
			discovers the inaccuracy some time later, and
			fails to take reasonable steps to inform HMRC.
		The amount of a penalty under this section may not exceed £3,000.
		Regulations may amend subsection (5) so as to substitute a different amountfor the amount for the time being specified there.
	Penalties for making prohibited payments
		A person is liable to a penalty under this section if—
			HMRC has given the person a warning notice under this section,
			at any time when the warning notice has effect, the person causes orpermits a prohibited payment to be made from a childcare account held by theperson, and
			the person is notified of an assessment under section 41 in respect of theprohibited payment.
		HMRC may give a person a warning notice under this section if—
			the person causes or permits a prohibited payment to be made from achildcare account held by the person,
			the person is notified of an assessment under section 41 in respect of theprohibited payment, and
			the assessment has become final (see subsection (7)).
		A warning notice is a notice which—
			subject to subsection (4), has effect for a period of 4 years beginningwith the day on which the notice is given (“the relevant 4-year period”), and
			states that the person will be liable to a penalty under this section if atany time during the relevant 4-year period the person causes or permits aprohibited payment to be made from a childcare account held by the person.
		If a person is notified of a penalty under this section, the warning noticegiven to the person under this section ceases to have effect.
		But subsection (4) does not prevent HMRC from giving the person a freshwarning notice as a result of the prohibited payment in respect of which theperson was notified of the penalty.
		Where a person is liable to a penalty under this section for causing orpermitting a prohibited payment to be made, the amount of the penalty is 25%of the amount assessed under section 41 in respect of the prohibited payment.
		For the purposes of this section an assessment under section 41 becomesfinal—
			in a case where the person does not apply for a review of the assessmentwithin the period specified in section 57(2)(a), at the end of that period,
			in a case where—
			the person applies for a review of the assessment but does not give noticeof an appeal against the assessment, and
			the assessment has not been cancelled,
				at the end of the period in which notice of an appeal against the assessmentcould have been given, or
			in a case where—
			notice of such an appeal has been given, and
			the assessment has not been quashed on appeal,
			on the day on which the appeal is determined or withdrawn.
		Accordingly— 
			if a person is granted an extension of the period for making an applicationfor a review of an assessment, any warning notice given to the person inrespect of the assessment before the application for the review is made is ofno effect, and
			if a person is permitted to give notice of an appeal against an assessmentafter the end of the period mentioned in subsection (7)(b), any warning noticegiven to the person in respect of the assessment before the notice of appealis given is of no effect.
	Penalties for dishonestly obtaining top-up payments, etc
		A person (“P”) is liable to a penalty under this section if—
			for the purpose of obtaining a relevant payment for P or another (seesubsection (2)), P does, or omits to do, any act, and
			P’s conduct involves dishonesty.
		The following payments are “relevant payments”—
			a top-up payment;
			a payment from a childcare account.
		The amount of the penalty may not exceed—
			£3,000, or
			the sum of any relevant amounts obtained as mentioned in subsection (1),
				whichever is greater.
		In subsection (3) “relevant amount” means—
			in the case of a top-up payment, the amount of the payment, and
			in the case of a payment from a childcare account, an amount equal to thetop-up element of the payment.
			(For provision about calculating the top-up element of a payment, see section21.)
		Regulations may amend subsection (3)(a) so as to substitute a differentamount for the amount for the time being specified there.
		Where— 
			a body corporate is liable to a penalty under this section, and
			the liability is attributable (wholly or partly) to the dishonesty of aperson falling within subsection (7),
			that person (as well as the body corporate) is liable to a penalty under thissection.
		The persons are—
			a director, manager, secretary or similar officer of the body corporate;
			any person who was purporting to act in such a capacity.

	Assessment and enforcement of penalties
		Where a person becomes liable to a penalty under this Act—
			HMRC may assess the penalty, and
			if they do so, they must notify the person.
		No assessment of a penalty may be made under this section after—
			the end of the period specified in subsection (3), or
			if earlier, the end of the period of 12 months beginning with the day onwhich HMRC first believed, or had reasonable grounds for believing, that theperson was liable to the penalty.
		The period referred to in subsection (2)(a) is—
			the period of 4 years beginning with the day on which the person becameliable to the penalty, or
			in a case where the person became liable to the penalty as a result of theperson’s dishonesty, the period of 20 years beginning with that day.
		Where a person is notified of an assessment under this section, the penaltypayable as a result of the assessment must be paid—
			in a case where the person does not apply for a review of the penaltywithin the period specified in section 57(2)(a), before the end of thatperiod,
			in a case where the person applies for a review of the penalty but does notgive notice of an appeal against the penalty, before the end of the period inwhich notice of such an appeal could have been given, or
			in a case where notice of such an appeal has been given, on the day onwhich the appeal is determined or withdrawn.
		A penalty under this Act may be enforced as if it were income tax chargedin an assessment and due and payable.
			See also section 53 (recovery of debts from childcare accounts).
	Double jeopardy
		A person is not liable to a penalty under this Act in respect of anything inrespect of which the person has been convicted of an offence.

Other enforcement powers
	Disqualification orders
		HMRC may make a disqualification order in relation to a person if conditionA, B or C is met.
		Condition A is that, on more than one occasion in the period of 4 yearsending with the day on which the disqualification order is made, the person—
			has become liable to a penalty under this Act, and
			has been notified of the penalty.
		Condition B is that—
			the person (“P”) has done, or omitted to do, any act for the purpose ofobtaining a relevant payment for P or another (see subsection (4)),
			P’s conduct involved dishonesty, and
			as a result P has been convicted of an offence or has been notified of apenalty under section 46.
		The following payments are “relevant payments”—
			a top-up payment;
			a payment from a childcare account.
		Condition C is that—
			the person (“P”) has done, or omitted to do, any act for the purpose ofobtaining a relevant benefit for P or another (see subsection (6)),
			P’s conduct involved dishonesty, and
			as a result P has been convicted of an offence.
		“Relevant benefit” means any benefit or other payment of a descriptionspecified in regulations.
		Where a disqualification order has effect in relation to a person—
			the person may not open a childcare account,
			no qualifying payments may be made into any childcare account held by theperson, and
			any declaration of eligibility made by the person for an entitlement periodfor which the order has effect is not valid.
		A disqualification order has effect for the period specified in the order.
		But a disqualification order may not have effect for a period longer than 3years.
		If HMRC make a disqualification order under this section, HMRC must give acopy of the order to—
			the person in relation to whom the order is made, and
			any person or body which provides childcare accounts.
		HMRC may revoke a disqualification order made under this section.
	Power to exclude childcare from being qualifying childcare
		This section applies if—
			a person has done, or omitted to do, any act for the purpose of obtaining apayment from a childcare account,
			the person’s conduct involved dishonesty, and
			as a result the person has been convicted of an offence or has beennotified of a penalty under section 46.
		HMRC may direct that any childcare provided by the person is not qualifyingchildcare for the purposes of this Act.
		A direction under this section has effect for 12 months beginning with theday on which it is made.
		Regulations may amend subsection (3) so as to substitute a different periodfor the period for the time being specified there.
		Where a direction under this section is made in relation to a person, thedirection also applies in relation to—
			any body corporate of which the person is a director or other officer,
			any body corporate of which the person is a member, if the affairs of thebody corporate are managed by its members, and
			any Scottish firm of which the person is a partner.
		HMRC must—
			give a copy of a direction under this section to—
			the person or persons in relation to whom it applies, and
			any person or body which provides childcare accounts, and
			publish the direction in the way appearing to HMRC to be best calculated tobring it to the attention of those who may be affected by it.
		HMRC may revoke a direction made under this section.
	Power to charge interest
		Where— 
			an amount has been assessed under section 41 or 47 as payable to HMRC by aperson under this Act, and
			some or all of the amount has not been paid to HMRC by the time specifiedin section 41(5) or 47(4) (as the case may be),
				HMRC may give the person a notice in writing requiring the person to payinterest on the amount that has not been paid (“the relevant debt”).
		If a notice is given to a person under this section, the relevant debtcarries interest for a period which—
			begins with the late payment interest start date (which may be earlier thanthe day on which the notice is given), and
			ends with the specified day or, if earlier, the day on which the relevantdebt is paid.
		“The late payment interest start date” means—
			in the case of an amount assessed under section 41, the day on which theperson became liable to pay it;
			in the case of a penalty, the day after the last day of the period withinwhich the penalty is required to be paid in accordance with section 47(4).
		“The specified day”, in relation to a notice given to a person under thissection, means—
			the day specified in the notice, or
			where on that day the relevant debt has not been paid, the day specified ina further notice given to the person by HMRC.
		The specified day must fall within the period of 6 months beginning withthe day on which the notice is given.
		Interest under this section is payable at the late payment interest rate.
		The “late payment interest rate” is—
			the rate provided for in regulations made by the Treasury under section103(1) of the Finance Act 2009, or
			if there is more than one such rate, the lowest such rate.
		Where two or more persons—
			have been notified of an assessment under section 41 in respect of the sameamount, and
			have been given a notice under this section,

	Deduction of recoverable amounts from tax credit awards

Reviews and appeals
	Appealable decisions
		A person who is affected by an appealable decision (see subsection (3)) mayappeal against the decision.
		But a person may not appeal against any decision unless—
			the person has applied under section 57 for a review of the decision, and
			either— 
			the person has been notified of the conclusion on the review, or
			the person has not been notified of the conclusion on the review and theperiod for notifying the person of that conclusion has ended.
		The following decisions are “appealable decisions”—
			a decision not to open a childcare account;
			a decision that a declaration of eligibility is not valid;
			a decision as to whether or not to make or revoke an account restrictionorder under section 24;
			a decision to give a person a notice under section 26;
			a decision to give a person a disqualification notice under section 34;
			a decision to make an assessment, or to make an assessment of a particularamount, under section 41;
			a decision to assess a penalty, or to assess a penalty of a particularamount, under section 47;
			a decision to make a disqualification order under section 49;
			a decision to make a direction under section 50;
			a decision to give a person a notice under section 51;
			a decision to give a direction under section 53.
		Where a person is notified of an appealable decision under this Act, thenotification must include details of the person’s right to apply for a reviewof the decision and to appeal against the decision.
		The effect of an appealable decision falling within paragraph (d), (f),(g), (j) or (k) of subsection (3) is suspended by—
			the making of an application for a review of the decision, or
			the making of an appeal against the decision.
		The effect of any other appealable decision is not suspended by the makingof such an application or appeal.
	Review of decisions
		A person who is affected by an appealable decision (“the applicant”) mayapply to the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs for a reviewof the decision.
		The application must be made—
			within the period of 30 days beginning with the day on which the applicantwas notified of the decision, or
			if the period for making the application has been extended under section58, within the extended period.
		The application must—
			be made in writing,
			contain sufficient information to identify the applicant and the decision,and
			set out the reasons for seeking a review of the decision.
		If an application for a review of a decision is made to the Commissionersin accordance with this section, the Commissioners must review the decision.
		On a review under this section, the Commissioners may—
			uphold the decision,
			vary the decision, or
			cancel the decision.
		If the applicant makes any representations to the Commissioners at a stagewhich gives the Commissioners a reasonable opportunity to consider them, theCommissioners must take account of them when carrying out the review.
		Where— 
			the Commissioners notify the applicant of further information or evidencewhich they may need for carrying out the review, and
			the information or evidence is not provided to them within the period of 15days beginning with the day on which the notice is given,
				the review may proceed without that information or evidence.
		The Commissioners must notify the applicant of the matters set out insubsection (9) within—
			the period of 30 days beginning with the day on which the Commissionersreceived the application for the review,
			if the applicant has been given a notice under subsection (7), the periodof 45 days beginning with that day, or
			such other period as the applicant and the Commissioners may agree.
		The matters referred to in subsection (8) are—
			the conclusion on the review,
			if the conclusion is that the decision is varied, details of the variation,and
			the reasons for the conclusion.
		If the Commissioners do not comply with subsection (8), the review is tobe treated as having concluded that the decision is upheld.
		In such a case, the Commissioners must notify the applicant of thatconclusion.
	Extension of time limit for applications for review
		A person who wishes to make an application for a review under section 57may apply to the Commissioners for an extension of the period for making theapplication.
		An application under this section—
			must be made before the end of the period of 6 months beginning with theday after the last day of the period mentioned in section 57(2)(a) (“thestandard period”), and
			must set out the reasons for seeking the extension.
		The Commissioners may grant an extension under this section if they aresatisfied that—
			due to special circumstances, it was not practicable for the person to makethe application under section 57 within the standard period, and
			it is reasonable in all the circumstances to grant the extension.
		If an application under this section is refused, it may not be renewed.
	Exercise of right of appeal
		An appeal under section 56 is to the appropriate tribunal.
		“The appropriate tribunal” means—
			the First-tier Tribunal, or
			in Northern Ireland, the appeal tribunal.
		“Appeal tribunal” means an appeal tribunal constituted under Chapter 1 ofPart 2 of the Social Security (Northern Ireland) Order 1998 ([S.I. 1998/1506(N.I. 10)](/id/nisi/1998/1506?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")).
		Regulations may provide for any provision contained in or made under thefollowing legislation to apply in relation to appeals under section 56, withsuch modifications as may be specified in regulations—
			Chapter 2 of Part 1 of the Social Security Act 1998 (social securityappeals: Great Britain);
			Chapter 2 of Part 2 of the Social Security (Northern Ireland) Order 1998(social security appeals: Northern Ireland);
			section 54 of the Taxes Management Act 1970 (settling of appeals byagreement).
	Powers of tribunal
		This section applies where a person is appealing to the Tribunal undersection 56 against an appealable decision.
		In a case where the appealable decision is a decision under section 47 toassess a penalty, or to assess a penalty of a particular amount, the Tribunalmay do any of the following—
			uphold the penalty;
			set aside the penalty;
			substitute for the penalty a penalty of an amount decided by the Tribunal.
		In any other case, the Tribunal must either—
			dismiss the appeal, or
			quash the whole or part of the decision to which the appeal relates.
		The Tribunal may act as mentioned in subsection (3)(b) only to the extentthat it is satisfied that the decision was wrong on one or more of thefollowing grounds—
			that the decision was based, wholly or partly, on an error of fact;
			that the decision was wrong in law.
		If the Tribunal quashes the whole or part of a decision, it may either—
			refer the matter back to HMRC with a direction to reconsider and make a newdecision in accordance with its ruling, or
			substitute its own decision for that of HMRC.
				This is subject to section 61(8).
		The Tribunal may not direct HMRC to take any action which they would nototherwise have the power to take in relation to the decision.
		A decision of the Tribunal made by virtue of this section has the sameeffect as, and may be enforced in the same manner as, a decision of HMRC.
		In this section “the Tribunal” means—
			the First-tier Tribunal, or
			in Northern Ireland, the appeal tribunal (within the meaning of section59(3)).
	Cases where there is more than one eligible person
		This section applies in the following cases.
		The first case is where—
			two or more persons (“the applicants”) have applied to open a childcareaccount in respect of the same child, and
			any of the applicants is appealing against a decision not to allow theapplicant to open a childcare account in respect of the child.
		The second case is where—
			one or more persons (“the applicants”) have applied to open a childcareaccount in respect of a child,
			another person (“the existing account-holder”) holds a childcare account inrespect of the child, and
			any of the applicants is appealing against a decision not to allow theapplicant to open a childcare account in respect of the child.
		The third case is where—
			a person is appealing against a decision not to make an account restrictionorder in relation to another person, or
			a person is appealing against a decision to make an account restrictionorder in relation to the person so as to enable another person to open achildcare account or make a declaration of eligibility in relation to such anaccount.
		In this section “the affected parties” means—
			in the case described in subsection (2), the applicants;
			in the case described in subsection (3), the applicants and the existingaccount-holder;
			in the case described in subsection (4), each of the persons mentioned inparagraph (a) or (b) of that subsection (as the case may be).
		Notice of the appeal must be given to each of the affected parties (otherthan the person bringing the appeal).
		Each of the affected parties is to be treated as a party to the appeal.
		If the Tribunal quashes the whole or part of the decision, it mustsubstitute its own decision for that of HMRC.
		A decision of the Tribunal made by virtue of this section has the sameeffect as, and may be enforced in the same manner as, a decision of HMRC.
		In this section “the Tribunal” has the same meaning as in section 60.

Compensatory payments
	Compensatory payments
		Where a person has in circumstances specified in regulations been deprivedof the opportunity to receive top-up payments in respect of a child for aperiod, HMRC must pay the person an amount equal to 20% of the costs incurredon qualifying childcare in respect of the child during the period.
		But the amount paid to a person by HMRC under this section for a period maynot exceed a maximum amount specified in, or determined in accordance with,regulations.
		The circumstances that may be specified in regulations under this sectioninclude, in particular—
			where an appealable decision is varied or cancelled on a review undersection 57, and
			where an appealable decision is quashed (whether wholly or partly) undersection 60.
		Payments may be made to a person under this section regardless of whetherthe person—
			has opened a childcare account, or
			has made a valid declaration of eligibility.
		Regulations may make further provision about making payments under thissection.
		Regulations may substitute a different percentage for the percentage forthe time being specified in subsection (1).
